reviewText:
If you can find my user review for the original Crysis I noted how the quality of its level design seems to fall off a cliff later in the campaign. A lot of other people will probably tell you this too. Warhead feels as if Crytek made it specifically to address that problem. It’s pretty much a more tightly-designed package of Crysis levels with a couple new weapons and vehicles.

If you were actually interested in what the original Crysis game’s story was about I don’t know what to say, but Warhead’s is slightly better. It’s kind of like the difference between Predator and The Rock respectively, the latter being slightly less cheesy, but still bombastic in its own way. Warhead follows Psycho (the British guy) and features a somewhat decently played-out character arc between him and a new supporting character. That’s all I think I can really say about it.

Aside from the original game’s suit powers, a new grenade launcher, EMP grenades which weaken nanosuit-equipped enemies (who are far more common in this expansion) but you as well, drivable APCs, and a couple new kinds of mounted gun, Warhead’s selling point is its superior level design compared to the original game. Luckily the level designers managed to stay strong throughout.

Crysis is a game that, behind its graphics, is hailed for open-ended mission design reminiscent of GoldenEye or Thief with huge maps. Ironically, almost all Warhead’s missions are pretty linear compared to the first game’s. But it manages to be linear without feeling like a Call of Duty-style corridor. It’s a very “wide” sort of linear.

The first mission ends with an open-ended base infiltration similar to some levels from Crysis, but after that everything is technically a straight line that still manages to give you a lot of options in how you play the game. The vehicle chase sequence immediately following that infiltration somehow doesn’t feel like a scripted event but instead simply has you follow a target within an open area. This is followed by what is, actually, a pretty well-done boss fight to contrast with the first game’s mediocre final boss. Afterwards there’s a section inside a battleship where Crytek actually manages to play some scripting tricks on you without automatically controlling the camera or putting you in a quick time event or anything. It’s almost more Half-Life 2 than Black Ops in this way. Warhead makes even its literal tunnels dynamic enough to let players have a say in how they tackle each combat situation, including a train section.

Visually, Warhead looks slightly better than the original Crysis but hasn’t had nearly as many mods made for it. Fortunately Crytek actually tried to optimize Warhead a bit so for most people the game should run better than Crysis. Warhead’s highest graphical features also aren’t locked behind DirectX 10.

Compared to the first Crysis, Warhead is kind of like the same meal with the same ingredients but prepared more diligently after the chef got some experience.

reviewText: Crysis Warhead's level design is noticeably different than that of Crysis 1. It still has both open and tight levels (which are alternated between for better pacing), but they are presented differently this time around. The open levels don't quite offer the same freedom of approach and alternate routes as the first game, presenting instead a wide but more straightforward route to your objective. The tighter sections are much better designed and are pretty fun to fight in. Warhead is also more action-oriented, often rushing you into a battle rather than letting you approach a potential encounter from a distance. Fortunately, the game still offers plenty of freedom and options for the player to handle confrontations. Improvements over the first game include the alien enemies, boss battles and vehicle controls. Overall, a short but highly enjoyable campaign.

reviewText:
This is a long review, so if you want a brief summary of why I recommend Crysis Warhead skip to Results and read from there.

Crytek creates another epic continuation onto the Crysis series. Crysis Warhead offers an alternative story from the eyes of Physco another one of the nano-tech marines.

Story:
On the same island as the original Crysis Warhead starts the story with Sergeant Sykes, Physco, who is on a vital mission to capture Korean cargo. It is up to you and your friend O’neil to push through the forces of North Korea and aliens alike to complete your objective.

Campaign:
The campaign consists of approximately seven missions, which vary in length. The campaign lasts anywhere from around four to seven hours depending on your play method. The initial missions are before are against human AI, but as you progress the enemy shift begins to occur as you start fighting less humans and engaging more aliens. The enemies, weapons, and abilities are the same as the original meaning this expansion only adds new missions and story. Regardless the campaign is well planned and the levels keep you wanting for me. They offer  dynamic play-styles that allow you to choose your completion style.

Gameplay:
As in the original the gameplay varies based on your difficulty. I played Delta and noticed most of the game was more about utilizing my cloak ability and catching enemies by surprise. The enemies will fire in the same place if you cloak and run, but if you hide for a few seconds they tend to forget you even existed and continue on with their business. Realistically this game is pretty fun and the combat can be dynamic – if you’re looking for run and gun you’d probably want to play on an easy difficulty. On the other hand if you’re more into sneak and strike then I’d recommend going for a harder difficulty. The abilities are fun, but you’ll notice you tend to use some over others. I rarely found myself using speed or super-strength, but instead almost exclusively cloak and shields (which auto selects when cloak deactivates).



Hints:
>If you cloak in mid battle and move prone most of the time you can avoid actually having to move as the enemies will be shooting above you.
>If you see a gun with an attachment you have make sure to drop your gun and exchange for that one. Otherwise you won’t unlock the attachment.
>The Plasma Accumulator Cannon only fires a short range then explodes sending missiles outwards.  This means to really damage your enemies you need to get close to them.
>IF you use a flashlight or a laser and cloak they can give away your position.

Results:
All and all Cyrsis Warhead is a great addition to the series and even if you didn’t play the first Crysis I would recommend giving it a go. It doesn’t really ruin any elements from the original if you play them backwards, but adds more depth to your Physco who in the first game seemed rather annoying. The campaign offers great complexity and amazing new environments. The graphics are of par to the original, annoyingly not 1080p, but still it looks good enough that you couldn’t tell anyway. I’d definitely recommend this game for someone who loves FPS games.

Pros:
+Suit abilities which allow you to change up your combat style.
+Loads of different weapons with unique attachments: silencers, lasers, flashlights, grenade launchers, etc.
+Decent enemy AI and good combat mix.
+Smooth difficulty curve accommodating for various skill levels.
+Good length campaign, which offers many new environments and combat scenarios.
+Good story and addition to the continuation of the series.

Cons:
-Not too many check points, you can manually save but sometimes you’d forget in the head of battle die and be warped back to what seems like the beginning of the level.

reviewText:
Crysis Warhead, technically a sequel to the original Crysis, you play as Psycho, a teammate of Nomad (the main character in the first game). At some point in the original Crysis, you two split up to handle separate missions, this game takes place right after that and ends right before you meet back up in the original, thus, it is a fairly short game.

Story: 8/10
Because it is in the same time-frame and environment as the original Crysis, not much needs to be explained. You already know what is going on, but at some points it felt kind of cheesy and forced, and you are also following this damned container that remains ever out of reach until the very end. Not a BAD story, besides, you are playing this for the fun of messing around most likely.

Graphics and Audio: 9/10
Despite a few points in the game where my framerate choked out, Crytek did a marvelous job with this game in terms of graphics. This game came out approximately a year after the original, which means they optimized their code and this didn't make my computer want to cry. It runs smoother and looks cleaner, and is completely action-packed from the get-go. Also, the cut scenes are in third person, which I feel is an improvement so you can see how your character is reacting to his situation as it develops. As far as audio, it sounds about the same quality as the original Crysis so all is good in this department.

Gameplay: 8/10
Same game as Crysis, but in my personal opinion, I had more fun before the aliens show up. I was looking forward to sneaking around and messing with my Korean enemies, and because this game starts so close to when all hell breaks loose, you don't really get a chance to do that. That aside, however, the controls feel really familiar and smooth, I was going to play with my Xbox controller but when it comes to FPS games, I prefer keyboard and mouse. By the way, the game is Gamepad enabled if you want it to be.

Overall: 9/10
It isn't the original Crysis, and that isn't necessarily BAD. The game is shorter and plays MUCH smoother, but I feel that the story in the original was slightly better. Both games are great and I recommend buying both. The game excels at showing what Crytek does really well, creating an action-packed blockbuster movie, but instead of the movie, it is a game, which is amazing.

Additionally, this game comes with Crysis Wars, apparently a Multiplayer Crysis, I didn't try it, have no interest.

A shorter, honed in take on Crysis, Warhead delivers a slightly tweaked take on the original game in a more linear, but excitement packed expansion.

There's a distinct change in tone between Crysis and Warhead and whilst the game largely plays the same, having a more vocal and at the very least charismatic main character gives Warhead a more personal touch than Crysis ever had. Coupled with gameplay changes, from minor changes to suit usage for increased usability and general effectiveness as well as overall level and encounter design, there's a different experience available here. It is much more focused on what it wants to deliver and does so at the expense of vast open enviroments, but not so much that there isn't plenty of room for you to breathe and negotiate the areas you're in. There's a perhaps greater emphasis on action as you're carried from encounter to encounter, but this generally feels like an improvement over potentially mundane driving sequences in the original.

The only major criticism I have of the game is its length. Whilst it maintains a brisk pace from start to finish, it does end after not too long a play-time, howerver it doesn't feel like a let down given its approach as a sort of side-quest from the main game. Of questionable worth in of itself, as an addition to Crysis it provides a really fun accompliament such that if the original was of interest, Warhead should certainly not be ignored.

reviewText:
Warhead was the successor of Crysis in 2008; a stand-alone expansion pack that was specifically released for PCs and, interestingly, did not require the original Crysis game to run. I remember this being praised for its better optimisation while the game at the same time had the exact same requirements as its predecessor. Also it looks better, there's not much difference, though, as it uses the same environments / assets as the original Crysis game.

The story is a tad bit unusual here - instead of this being a continuation to Crysis it actually takes place at the same time. However, the game puts us in the shoes of Psycho instead of Nomad. We pick up the story just after the two buddies get separated - with Psycho alone there's more focus on fighting the Korean military (initially, that is) as the emphasis is on retrieving / destroying the nuclear warhead they have in their possession (hence the title). I liked the in-game cutscenes they made for the game and the fact that we have a Korean colonel as the game's antagonist.

The campaign is, being part of an expansion pack, shorter than that of Crysis but is a BLAST! I found it more action-packed and interesting (even though we know there are aliens rampant on the island which is not a surprise anymore). Since multiplayer services no longer exist (see the disclaimer re GameSpy on the store page) there's no point in elaborating on that one.

Perhaps there's a solution for that, but this would definitely be something unofficial. Thus, at this point, this game is only worth purchasing for its short but satisfying campaign content. If discounted, it may just be a decent purchase and then you can make up your mind whether or not you want to see what Crytek achieved with Crysis 2.

That shows that they actually value PC gaming and did not cash in with consoles the same way they did later on with crysis titles *cough* Crysis 2 and 3 *cough*.

Gameplay - Now on to the gameplay: Solid. The gunplay is enjoyable and lots of different attachments which provides different opptunities against each enemy type. Each enemy is varied: From humans having a similar arsenal to you, flying squid aliens which ambush you and vehicles such as helis, jeeps and apcs that will need strategy to beat rather than a bigger gun, though that helps. Might I add that you can also drive them. You can see why I like this game? On top of that the nano suit brings you a new strategy to complete your objective. Armour making you a tank to go guns blazing, Stealth to be a cloak and dagger, dash to completely evade any enemy and strength to just throw ♥♥♥♥ at people. The game is so varied in how you approach objectives and how you complete them because of the open world map and the nano suit. Great in terms of depth and playstyles. Only drawback is the story which is very B-movie. It keeps the game going and gives you an excuse to enter new environments. The story is very generic; aliens evade, take them out, done. Its forgettable and basic so don’t buy it for that it’s the gameplay and graphics this rocks at.

Replayability - A lot. With the playstyle, different weapons, attachments, routes, vehicles and pace can give totally new experiences. Not more to say then the time it took me I enjoyed every bit due to its flexibity and freedom lacking in game today.

Conclusion - If you can’t tell I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game. Everything besides story just shows the potential and the missed chance many games coming out miss. It’s not about building a story then putting in gameplay. Gameplay is what makes this game because it only focuses on that and as a result it’s amazing and competes with many games out now. Any playstyle is rewarded with the nano suit, weapons, attachments and vehicles. You probably have got it but if you don’t, GET IT. MUST BUY!

reviewText:
In the original Crysis, you fought off North Koreans, discovered an extra-terrestrial plot, and began the fight for humanity, all as the special-ops agent codenamed Nomad. But as you saved the day in the main storyline, your cohort Psycho was off on his own mission. Warhead shows you what he was up to, by putting you in his head and unleashing you against the dastardly enemies who stand in your nanosuit-powered way.

Crysis is an open-ended first-person shooter in which how you proceed is really up to you. Set on a beautiful tropical island filled with lush scenery, flora and fauna, you're equipped with a special nanosuit that allows you to cloak, speed up, increase your strength, or increase your defence. This nanosuit affords you a number of options in how you want to take on your enemies: do you sneak up behind them, grab hold of your target, and toss them into their ally? Or do you stay in the underbrush from a mile away and pick off your targets with a rifle? Of course, you can always just run into battle, guns-a-blazing, if that's your thing. Or punch everything with super strength, sending it skidding across the ground. The possibilities are endless, and it leads to replay certain encounters again and again, just to see the different results.

Warhead doesn't really deviate too much from this formula, but that's alright, because it doesn't need to. Some level design does change, though. Levels are fairly smaller in this expansion, but with more in them. In the original, while you spent most of your time walking through long, lush, but boring valleys, this one had the action more condensed. The pacing is much improved, leading to less running around and more shooting/punching/tossing/humiliating your foes. Overall the game can last about six to seven hours, depending on your play style, so while it not be a lengthy campaign, it's a good addendum to the original's plot.

Additionally, as opposed to the sudden appearance of aliens doesn't suddenly eliminate the Korean presence on the island like it did in the first game. Both groups will show up as your aggressors throughout the game, sometimes at the same time. This leads to you being able to get them to combat each other, letting you either slink away in the firefight or simply eliminate the last remaining forces.

Crytek have also stated that the graphics have been optimized, and therefore aren't as system-taxing as the original Crysis. While I've heard some reports to verify this, I've also heard that there are some problems with how the game goes about its graphical business. While I didn't directly notice these problems with the exception of an odd framerate hiccup, reports of unreasonable slowdown and graphical glitches are somewhat common.

While Crysis: Warhead doesn't really bring anything new to the series gameplay-wise, the expanded-upon storyline and better pacing of the game will intrigue any that enjoyed the original Crysis. Wide open settings, fast-paced action, and the ability to fling someone across a great distance make it a fun game to play, especially with all the different ways to approach a situation. So, while it may not be everyone's cup of tea, if you enjoy a bit of choice with your explosions, and enjoyed the original, Warhead is definitely the game for you.

Crysis Warhead represents the apex of the Crytek sandbox FPS genre. This is the one and only time the formula's been applied flawlessly. Far Cry 1 brims with promise but is plagued with staggeringly unfair AI and bad checkpointing that can make the game sometimes unfun. Crysis 1 starts off incredible but devolves into linear COD-esque nonsense two-thirds of the way through. After Warhead, Crysis got consolized and turned into a generic linear shooter, and Far Cry got open-worldized and turned into a generic Ubigame.

But, for the brief duration of Crysis Warhead's 7-hour running time, the style is done perfectly. It's linear, of course, in the sense that you need to go from point A to point B, but there are innumerable paths to take and a variety of available playstyles. Want to stealth through most of the game? No problem! Want to kill everybody? No problem! There is a slightly more linear train level, but you can just jump off the train and sneak through the woods if you want (in fact, on the highest difficulty, you have to - staying on top of the train means insta-death).

The story is inconsequential and won't make sense if you haven't played Crysis 1, and the game's still a system melter just like the original, but neither of those things diminish how much fun it is to play around in these environments. Thankfully, this game has quick save, so you can play around to your heart's content and try different things without worrying.

Definitely worth the $20 asking price.

reviewText:
Crysis Warhead offers more of the same compared to the original, but not much more.

Pros: Graphics, Sound, Controls
Cons: Story, Gameplay, Bugs, Multiplayer

Crysis Warhead boast lush, beautiful graphics that most machines can now handle.  The sounds and music mesh just as well with the story and setting.  Controls are mostly clean and crisp, but some features (such as hold-down aim) are either poor or nonexistent.

The story doesn't deviate from the original which leaves something to be desired given the original's inadequacy.  Gameplay is boring if not consistent: Korean soldiers and alien spawn will fill most of the kill count.  Bugs may sometimes necessitate a reload, but nothing too major.  Multiplayer is nonexistent, but it would still be virtually nonexistent playerwise if its nonexistence were nonexistent.

Crysis Warhead offers a little more than the original, but too little more than everything else.

6/10

reviewText: More of the same, but better. That is what I can conclude after finishing Crysis Warhead. You play through the events of Crysis, but with another character and thus from another point of view. A nice approach. The game also still looks fantastic, but is far better optimized giving a better experience thoughout the entire campaign. So, nothing more to say really, great game!

While Crysis 1 asked for an insane gaming PC back in the day (which made my old pc to crash over and over again on the final stage) Crysis Warhead was refined and optimized and we were finally able to play with not that many graphic issues, the game is actually pretty good and gets you hooked inmediately, the events occur at the same time that Crysis 1 develops.\n\nYou are Psycho, another soldier with a special suit that makes you super human. Though, it may appear you get more of the same, the game offers some new weapons and battle escenarios and vehicles, if you like the first Crysis, you will like this one too, shorter in length, but still enjoyable!
Best looking game ever, and greate gameplay as well.
Become Jason Statham and beat up Koreans
very kool\n
Starring: JASON STATHAHAHAM as Every bald badass ever

While the game is weaker in the story department at the beginning, it begins to pick up around the end. Psycho is a very believeable character and several of his personality are shown which makes for a character that you can connect to quite easily.

Despite being mediocre in story, the game makes up more it in gameplay. The game is extremely fun and is worth playing through several times. Alien fights are epic and require you to plan your actions carefully, or you will likely get caught in an ambush which will require on-the-fly planning and precise movements. AI in this game is a little braindead, but they do well and help you through tight spots in the game's campaign.

However, as with every Crysis game I have played, it is my opinion that driving in any one of them is atrocious. Controls are awkward and confusing as both the A D keys control view as does the mouse which takes a lot of getting used to. The vehicles are also incredibly bouncy and get thrown around.

Overall: 8.5/10

The original Crysis was a technical phenomenon with a lot of great elements that worked, and Warhead is the exact same game with a different setting. This is both good and bad, but more positives than anything. You play Psycho, one of the special forces soldiers who was sent in with the original game’s Nomad. This is his story and what happened to him while separated from Nomad. While the core story of Crysis wasn’t too interesting there is a better mix between the open world and corridors. The game still gives you the option to choose to approach each objective by sneaking, sniping, driving, or guns blazing.

The game has more of a variety of objectives such as a train ride, and killing the larger aliens which can be pretty fun. There aren’t any new weapons, and everything is pretty much the same. If you’re looking for Crysis 2.5 with this you’re going to be disappointed. While the game plays exactly like the first there are more cinematic moments such as running from a giant alien, and towards the end the game gets really epic. There are more aliens involved this time around instead of just mostly KPA soldiers. I still would have liked to see different alien types, and maybe make the game a bit more scripted since the game is so short.

The game still looks the same with no graphical improvements at all. You still need an ultra powerful machine to run this on highest settings with DirectX10. Even my monster computer struggles to keep the FPS at a non-choppy rate during large firefights. The game is also more forgiving this time around as I only died maybe a dozen times during the whole campaign. The mass of enemies are easier to take on since the game seems to feel more balanced and the close quarters environments seem to be designed for this too.

While I wish there would have been new weapons, new enemies, and totally new locales it works with the game’s story. Warhead will really make Crysis fans happy and add an extra 4-5 hours and give you more of a back story to what happened to the strange Psycho.

Crysis Warhead is something of a mixed bag for me. I played it almost immediately after Crysis, and all sorts of strangeness abounds. For example, I played Crysis on maximum settings and didn't notice anything (aside from the occasional frame rate drop in larger levels) that would impact gameplay from a tech side of the house.

But Warhead? I had to turn everything down. I wanted that 60 fps sweet spot... but it wasn't happening without minimum settings. I didn't play it on minimum, I compromised for about 40 fps, so I could actually see things like grass (which is necessary for my play style, as I like to be the Predator and kill from stealth). I'm curious as to why this stripped down expansion was literally more taxing on my system than the 2013 Tomb Raider (also played on max - but without the PhysX hair).

It may be the combination of age, poor optimization, and video drivers (which age has a pretty big factor on whether or not your drivers will play nice with the game) that prevented me from getting the sort of performance I was getting with the original game (plus, the original game underwent a series of performance patches after it was released).

The gameplay is essentially unchanged, which is good if you like it (I do). All the old weapons are present, though they did add a couple of new ones. However... again, the overpowered alien enemies rear their ugly heads (as expected) and the game becomes less fun as a result. You basically have to carry the gauss rifle at that point forward, and cloaking is a waste of time from there on in. Worse, like before, as soon as the aliens arrive, you're given linear paths and objectives (though Warhead is in general, more linear than the original).

Story wise, I like Warhead better, mostly because you play as Psycho and get some great character development out of the experience. From the first game, the only thing I knew about him was that he was British and slightly sarcastic. And that his callsign probably meant he was a daredevil or just deranged. Psycho is much more interesting than Nomad, and actively defies orders at certain points for fairly justified reasons.

I actively despised the Korean general who is the antagonist of Warhead, and hated it whenever he got the upper hand on Psycho, but the ending was made all the sweeter for it.

On the whole, I recommend Warhead for fans of the first game, with the caveat that it has the same issues of said first game, as well as a few new ones. It's also short, about half the play time of the original Crysis (which I think is fine - it doesn't overstay its welcome).

I only got round to playing Crysis in 2015, although I've been meaning to for years! I have now also played warhead, the followup which takes you through the same timeframe but on the other end of the island, playing as Psycho instead of Nomad. The game is identical in most ways to the previous one, so I'm copy-pasting much of what I wrote about that here.

From what I'd seen prior to playing Crysis, I was under the impression that you'd play a kind of semi-indestructable super soldier in this game, dashing and jumping around at high speed and slicing through dozens of enemy soldiers with ease, but really it plays more like you're just a fairly standard FPS soldier dude with a few perks. I found myself not bothering with things like the stealth and speed mode very often as they both drain your energy incredibly quickly. On hard difficulty, a few well-placed enemy bullets can still take you down if you're not careful so you don't really feel invulnerable.

The gameplay is fairly standard FPS fare, akin to Call Of Duty or whatever, with open-ish world elements but lots of set pieces. The game world never feels as open as, say, the Far Cry series and you are pretty much railroaded into tackling things in order, though how you approach each set piece is up to you and you do feel that you can take a variety of approaches to solve the obstacles you encounter.

The graphics have really stood the test of time, It didn't feel particularly dated.

The Crysis campaign only took me 10 hours to play through and I didn't exactly rush through it. Warhead was even shorter, at a shade over 6 hours! The storyline is very standard and unengaging, following a rather cliched 'US saves the world from alien invasion that is unwittingly aided by the nasty Asians' formula that's all too familiar by now. In this iteration, you play as stereotypical Brit hardman with a heart of gold Psycho, who constantly has to remind the racially stereotypical Korean baddies that he's a Brit, not a Yankee. Warhead's plot and ending were even weaker than the first game, sadly.

Overall, I'd say that if you've never played Crysis before, play that first. If you enjoy playing that game, this is just more of exactly the same! Pick them both up when on sale with a heavy discount and you can't go wrong, really.

Impressions & Score:

Story: 9.5 out of 10
This is an expansion for Crysis, not a new game and is intended to tell the story of Psycho,  one of your teammates in Crysis I. During the story in Crysis I, Psycho get separated from Nomad, in order to fulfill another important mission. This new story is quite good and it's connected to the story in Crysis I, which is awesome. Even though it doesn't provide too much info about aliens and characters, I liked the way it was linked to the main story, so this is why I gave a better score.

Graphics: 10 out of 10
The graphics are almost the same as for Crysis I but with some improvements in details in almost everything. This is quite a good thing, I didn't quite noticed at first, but after checking some videos on youtube, the differences are pretty big. If I could have given a better score, I would, this expansion is improved on almost every aspect.

Gameplay: 9.5 out of 10
First of all, I like to mention that this game is a bit harder than Crysis I, but this isn't because of AI improvement, but mostly because of more difficult enemies throught the game. While in the first Crysis, you fought KPA soldiers over 50 % of the game (which were quite weak even on Delta difficulty), in this DLC you'll only fight KPA soldiers during the first 10 % of the game. Instead of KPA soldiers, in Crysis Warhead you'll fight a lot of KPA Special Ops (which are bassically nano suit soldiers just like yourself), which are pretty damn good. The producers also included some alien packs that are immune to damage until you destroy the one that generates their shield. All this makes the game a bit more challenging than the first Crysis, which is a good improvement from my point of view. They also added new vehicules and new weapons like grenade launcher, new pistols, new grenades, all this further improves the overall gameplay. Great job !

Audio: 10 out of 10
The audio is similar to the previous Crysis, so that means is excellent. Didn't noticed any differences here.

AI Behavior: 9.5 out of 10
The AI is better, because you don't have to fight too many KPA soldiers, instead you have to fight a lot of aliens, KPA Special Ops and some bosses. The KPA Special Ops are quite good because they use nano grenades to deactivate your suit before moving to attack, the aliens instead, have the same behavior like in Crysis I, so for more details see that review.

Multiplayer: not tested
As with Crysis I, I couldn't test the multiplayer since the servers were deactivated. There are some instructions on the internet on how you can play multiplayer, but I didn't bother to try.

Overall: 9.7 out 10
A lot of improvements done in this expansion compared to the previous Crysis, that makes this game even better. On top of all this, Crysis Warhead is a stand alone game and doesn't require the original Crysis to be played, but in my opionion is very recommended that you play the first Crysis before checking Crysis Warhead, so that you may have a better understanding of what is happening during the storyline. 100 % recommend, a true clasic masterpiece to the fps genre.

Background:
See my earlier review for Crysis the original.  This time you play as Psycho during the sections spent apart from Nomad (the player) in the original game.  This game looks the same but runs smoother on modern cards (GTX 970) and all but the hardest difficulty now use auto ammo pickup which is so much better.  Vehicles start in third person.  The UI isn't really improved from the first
date:
though it tries.  There are definitely more weapons to play with but it doesn't change much.  This game is very clearly the polished version of Crysis original.  Way more fairly long cut scenes.

Gameplay:
Another first person shooter in a mostly open world.  This one is more linear but has less sections that you get stuck working through and hate.
You start off with all suit powers (hold middle click and drag in a direction):
- default is armor which includes faster health regen
- then cloak is overpowered (drains power as you move and drops if you attack) yet fails at melee range.
- strength makes you jump higher and absorb more falling damage
- speed makes you run faster
recommended:
really fast for a short time

Good to know:
Fairly unforgiving again (seriously consider playing on easy and you will still die a bunch).
Falling damage can kill (use strength to minimize).
You can breath underwater.
There's also a separate night vision that drains a separate power meter.
Armored vehicles require explosives to destroy.
You can only carry a few kinds of weapons at a time
